Express

# 

<span key="173d5322fe33470cab8f64b189910369"><span offset-key="173d5322fe33470cab8f64b189910369:0">For starters, what is express JS¿</span></span>

<span key="7f0ba48c3b8e43228ef908c18a21bb00"><span offset-key="7f0ba48c3b8e43228ef908c18a21bb00:0">When introduced, node.js gave developers the chance to use JavaScript to write software that, up to that point, could only be written using lower level languages like C, C++, Java, Python…</span></span>

<span key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2"><span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:0">This tutorial will cover how to write </span>**web services**<span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:2"> that can communicate with clients (the front end application) using </span>**J**<span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:4">ava</span>**S**<span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:6">cript </span>**O**<span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:8">bject </span>**N**<span offset-key="dfce8735f13b48468021e2e8bcb407a2:10">otation (JSON).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="a950bb76bdbd4af2a30ff0c0abeab2bf"><span offset-key="a950bb76bdbd4af2a30ff0c0abeab2bf:0">JavaScript is asynchronous, which allows us to take full advantage of the processor it’s running on. Taking full advantage of the processor is crucial because the node process will be running on a single CPU.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="d5e50c4ac1c64ee987054cca24658a53"><span offset-key="d5e50c4ac1c64ee987054cca24658a53:0">Using JavaScript gives us access to the npm repository. This repository is the largest ecosystem of useful libraries (most of them free to use) in </span>**npm modules**<span offset-key="d5e50c4ac1c64ee987054cca24658a53:2">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="51237cf54153495a9c9cb185d1f5a198"><span offset-key="51237cf54153495a9c9cb185d1f5a198:0">Explain what Node.js is and its core features</span></span>

<span key="f7674cfee40d4b5daca671ce6db683bd"><span offset-key="f7674cfee40d4b5daca671ce6db683bd:0">Traditionally, developers only used the JavaScript language in web browsers. But, in 2009, </span>**Node.js**<span offset-key="f7674cfee40d4b5daca671ce6db683bd:2"> was unveiled, and with it, the developer tool kit expanded greatly. Node.js gave developers the chance to use JavaScript to write software that, up to that point, could only be written using C, C++, Java, Python, Ruby, C#, and the like.</span></span>

<span key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c"><span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:0">We will use Node to write server code. Specifically, </span>**web services**<span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:2"> that can communicate with clients using the </span>**J**<span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:4">ava</span>**S**<span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:6">cript </span>**O**<span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:8">bject </span>**N**<span offset-key="378b072dbfe54436a4c174eb9d65fb6c:10">otation (JSON) format for data interchange.</span></span>

<span key="99d7a4f1513a4f37b10979aedaeb7cff"><span offset-key="99d7a4f1513a4f37b10979aedaeb7cff:0">Some of the advantages of using Node.js for writing server-side code are:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="81060cf0ee8842d5bfbb67cccf414c74"><span offset-key="81060cf0ee8842d5bfbb67cccf414c74:0">Uses the same programming language (JavaScript) and paradigm for both client and server. Using the same language, we minimize context switching and make it easy to share code between the client and the server.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="69345e5092e84c38a8082276818ce7e1"><span offset-key="69345e5092e84c38a8082276818ce7e1:0">JavaScript is single-threaded, which removes the complexity involved in handling multiple threads.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="f572ab154bbb4762a716202bb6893544"><span offset-key="f572ab154bbb4762a716202bb6893544:0">JavaScript is asynchronous, which allows us to take full advantage of the processor it’s running on. Taking full advantage of the processor is crucial because the node process will be running on a single CPU.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="1f2ec661ce2b486fb40253583fe0eaec"><span offset-key="1f2ec661ce2b486fb40253583fe0eaec:0">Using JavaScript gives us access to the npm repository. This repository is the largest ecosystem of useful libraries (most of them free to use) in </span>**npm modules**<span offset-key="1f2ec661ce2b486fb40253583fe0eaec:2">.</span></span>

<span key="6fb9d45cbc474e21a67dc08bd05401e7"><span offset-key="6fb9d45cbc474e21a67dc08bd05401e7:0">Some of the disadvantages of using Node.js for writing server-side code are:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="b8ee37fa455c40b590237861e81f9440"><span offset-key="b8ee37fa455c40b590237861e81f9440:0">By strictly using JavaScript on the server, we lose the ability to use the right tool (a particular language) for the job.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="e574df309a6a4a79b6be54d2da5fb033"><span offset-key="e574df309a6a4a79b6be54d2da5fb033:0">Because JavaScript is single-threaded, we can’t take advantage of servers with multiple cores/processors.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="4f0e80464572468bb46a5b368b819a6f"><span offset-key="4f0e80464572468bb46a5b368b819a6f:0">Because JavaScript is asynchronous, it is harder to learn for developers that have only worked with languages that default to synchronous operations that block the execution thread.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="64eb8f6456474018b19b316d53c654a8"><span offset-key="64eb8f6456474018b19b316d53c654a8:0">In the npm repository, there are often too many packages that do the same thing. This excess of packages makes it harder to choose one and, in some cases, may introduce vulnerabilities into our code.</span></span>

<span key="5b157791fd864398b836dd53a8ed4713"><span offset-key="5b157791fd864398b836dd53a8ed4713:0">To write a simple web server with </span>`Node.js`<span offset-key="5b157791fd864398b836dd53a8ed4713:2">:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="a04816075c074c9da6c9caefb09f8875"><span offset-key="a04816075c074c9da6c9caefb09f8875:0">Use Node’s </span>`HTTP`<span offset-key="a04816075c074c9da6c9caefb09f8875:2"> module to abstract away complex network-related operations.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="65082e874fa349ac81bb0e768b5e7eb1"><span offset-key="65082e874fa349ac81bb0e768b5e7eb1:0">Write the single </span>***request handler***<span offset-key="65082e874fa349ac81bb0e768b5e7eb1:2"> function to handle all requests to the server.</span></span>

<span key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71"><span offset-key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71:0">The request handler is a function that takes the </span>`request`<span offset-key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71:2"> coming from the client and produces the </span>`response`<span offset-key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71:4">. The function takes two arguments: 1) an object representing the </span>`request`<span offset-key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71:6"> and 2) an object representing the </span>`response`<span offset-key="371b052970274f1fab60a07e4e38cb71:8">.</span></span>

<span key="a04285359c5d493db43101c6965483f1"><span offset-key="a04285359c5d493db43101c6965483f1:0">This process works, but the resulting code is verbose, even for the simplest of servers. Also, note that when using only Node.js to build a server, we use a single request handler function for all requests.</span></span>

# 

<span key="67c718e0223145da8e2665aab9fb9e8f"><span offset-key="67c718e0223145da8e2665aab9fb9e8f:0">Try It Out:</span></span>

<span key="f517aba59f4243a89165197dcb78bfb2"><span offset-key="f517aba59f4243a89165197dcb78bfb2:0">Using only Node.js, let’s write a simple web server that returns a message. Create a folder for the server and add an </span>`index.js`<span offset-key="f517aba59f4243a89165197dcb78bfb2:2"> file inside.</span></span>

<span key="7f3e5d10450b4a32b277810886a0fba1"><span offset-key="7f3e5d10450b4a32b277810886a0fba1:0">Next, add the following code to the </span>`index.js`<span offset-key="7f3e5d10450b4a32b277810886a0fba1:2"> file:</span></span>

1

<span key="a5abbd595eaf488192a44e1bfaaf43bd"><span offset-key="a5abbd595eaf488192a44e1bfaaf43bd:0">const http = require("http"); // built in node.js module to handle http trafficconst hostname = "127.0.0.1"; // the local computer where the server is running</span></span>

2

<span key="172d919a0c244b9fb9fb6102b30da62f"><span offset-key="172d919a0c244b9fb9fb6102b30da62f:0">const port = 3000; // a port we'll use to watch for trafficconst server = http.createServer((req, res) => {</span></span>

3

<span key="55e3abc5af884776b73b04d0c10655d4"><span offset-key="55e3abc5af884776b73b04d0c10655d4:0"> // creates our server</span></span>

4

<span key="f004e25327f74f828230551b666be03e"><span offset-key="f004e25327f74f828230551b666be03e:0"> res.statusCode = 200; // http status code returned to the client</span></span>

5

<span key="6d5dd4763dad4388a78ac4bb45eaee2e"><span offset-key="6d5dd4763dad4388a78ac4bb45eaee2e:0"> res.setHeader("Content-Type", "text/plain"); // inform the client that we'll be returning text</span></span>

6

<span key="5ab1b7d5f9134f7989f316349b839c83"><span offset-key="5ab1b7d5f9134f7989f316349b839c83:0"> res.end("Hello World from Node\\\\n"); // end the request and send a response with the specified message</span></span>

7

<span key="52cccf446a4f4db89daac54c7f2af379"><span offset-key="52cccf446a4f4db89daac54c7f2af379:0">});server.listen(port, hostname, () => {</span></span>

8

<span key="def6c7ba819448ebbe24cf2044c9a4ba"><span offset-key="def6c7ba819448ebbe24cf2044c9a4ba:0"> // start watching for connections on the port specified</span></span>

9

<span key="41f12cde4edb492c9827deba60ff5925"><span offset-key="41f12cde4edb492c9827deba60ff5925:0"> console.log(\`Server running at &lt;http://gt;{hostname}:${port}/\`);</span></span>

10

<span key="53292d1590854b749c648d6b1d1f1edd"><span offset-key="53292d1590854b749c648d6b1d1f1edd:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

<span key="12dad8220f664cdca936118761a686d6"><span offset-key="12dad8220f664cdca936118761a686d6:0">Now navigate to the folder in a terminal/console window and type: </span>`node index.js`<span offset-key="12dad8220f664cdca936118761a686d6:2"> to execute your file. A message that reads "\_Server running at \_</span></span><a href="http://127.0.0.1:3000" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="af54d917144540f38612c2058d01c200" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="b776752166ab45d78096d33d3ecd1619"><em>http://127.0.0.1:3000</em></span></span></a><span key="4cc9784274664ca3a404d1d8ecd3b78f"><span offset-key="4cc9784274664ca3a404d1d8ecd3b78f:0">" should be displayed, and the server is now waiting for connections.</span></span>

<span key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799"><span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:0">Open a browser and visit: </span>`http://localhost:3000`<span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:2">. </span>`localhost`<span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:4"> and the IP address </span>`127.0.0.1`<span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:6"> point to the same thing: your local computer. The browser should show the message: "</span>*Hello World from Node*<span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:8">". There you have it, your first web server, built from scratch using nothing but </span>`Node.js`<span offset-key="1c5a105fe5bc4d51bba5c51640ceb799:10">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="7f83104dae7444de85dcffc6810b0157"><span offset-key="7f83104dae7444de85dcffc6810b0157:0">Explain what Express is and its core features:</span></span>

<span key="b3009a5d07a240c2a861ec7e9ce4c92e"><span offset-key="b3009a5d07a240c2a861ec7e9ce4c92e:0">Node’s built-in </span>`HTTP`<span offset-key="b3009a5d07a240c2a861ec7e9ce4c92e:2"> module provides a powerful way to build web applications and services. However, it requires a lot of code for everyday tasks like sending an HTML page to the browser.</span></span>

<span key="742252641e6a4b7b8b521b6e6450ea85"><span offset-key="742252641e6a4b7b8b521b6e6450ea85:0">Introducing Express, a light and unopinionated framework that </span>**sits on top of Node.js**<span offset-key="742252641e6a4b7b8b521b6e6450ea85:2">, making it easier to create web applications and services. Sending an HTML file or image is now a one-line task with the </span>`sendFile`<span offset-key="742252641e6a4b7b8b521b6e6450ea85:4"> helper method in </span>`Express`<span offset-key="742252641e6a4b7b8b521b6e6450ea85:6">.</span></span>

<span key="09a924f601a740efa57f208892cef32c"><span offset-key="09a924f601a740efa57f208892cef32c:0">Ultimately, Express is </span>**just a Node.js module**<span offset-key="09a924f601a740efa57f208892cef32c:2"> like any other module.</span></span>

<span key="80eb1d84bfba43aa801feefa40bfaf2b"><span offset-key="80eb1d84bfba43aa801feefa40bfaf2b:0">What can we do with Express? So many things! For example:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="55f89abc58f846deb454d67d5850c7fa"><span offset-key="55f89abc58f846deb454d67d5850c7fa:0">Build web applications.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="1297c05148e94632aea141b905ffe7af"><span offset-key="1297c05148e94632aea141b905ffe7af:0">Serve </span>*Single Page Applications*<span offset-key="1297c05148e94632aea141b905ffe7af:2"> (SPAs).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c6171061395f49d69bf726c0b2f41c8a"><span offset-key="c6171061395f49d69bf726c0b2f41c8a:0">Build RESTful web services that work with JSON.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="65e3fc8c6a864c0588ec59355ab4e361"><span offset-key="65e3fc8c6a864c0588ec59355ab4e361:0">Serve static content, like HTML files, images, audio files, PDFs, and more.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="e97137d14e2b4d6b904550c963c2b9c8"><span offset-key="e97137d14e2b4d6b904550c963c2b9c8:0">Power real-time applications using technologies like </span>**Web Sockets**<span offset-key="e97137d14e2b4d6b904550c963c2b9c8:2"> or </span>**WebRTC**<span offset-key="e97137d14e2b4d6b904550c963c2b9c8:4">.</span></span>

<span key="cab2a7c6fcd7440dacffdeab0d82364e"><span offset-key="cab2a7c6fcd7440dacffdeab0d82364e:0">Some of the benefits of using Express are that it is:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="54d3ec59ae3a43a9a9f86a7e5057d97e"><span offset-key="54d3ec59ae3a43a9a9f86a7e5057d97e:0">Simple</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="77091a901651465c8045d4dc9f9a9cae"><span offset-key="77091a901651465c8045d4dc9f9a9cae:0">Unopinionated</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="44f9ca296db044aa9731fd16dc78bb2c"><span offset-key="44f9ca296db044aa9731fd16dc78bb2c:0">Extensible</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="860fb90d11e047c78ffaed5539427346"><span offset-key="860fb90d11e047c78ffaed5539427346:0">Light-weight</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="6ffc3e232fdc4669858ce51d98e2aacf"><span offset-key="6ffc3e232fdc4669858ce51d98e2aacf:0">Compatible with </span></span><a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/connect" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bf67fb177c9a413c95275c6f9769a69e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="9ec5a5cb15854ce2a5e5803cbbe695c7"><span data-offset-key="9ec5a5cb15854ce2a5e5803cbbe695c7:0">connect middleware (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="f6c68572ca0f41f8b75fcd4d9e656ed3"><span offset-key="f6c68572ca0f41f8b75fcd4d9e656ed3:0">. This compatibility means we can tap into an extensive collection of modules written for </span>`connect`<span offset-key="f6c68572ca0f41f8b75fcd4d9e656ed3:2">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="2980896b370240219d8e45db57f79fe5"><span offset-key="2980896b370240219d8e45db57f79fe5:0">All packaged into a clean, intuitive, and easy-to-use API.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4d4e6e8d65b4401e9c884380aa25085c"><span offset-key="4d4e6e8d65b4401e9c884380aa25085c:0">Abstracts away common tasks (writing web applications can be verbose, hence the need for a library like this).</span></span>

<span key="c8258e5362194b4d98eff20ea669ce50"><span offset-key="c8258e5362194b4d98eff20ea669ce50:0">Some of the drawbacks of Express are:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="894b71832fd540699a5f0694b8b3524c"><span offset-key="894b71832fd540699a5f0694b8b3524c:0">It’s not a one-stop solution. Because of its simplicity, it does very little out of the box. Especially when compared to frameworks like </span>**Ruby on Rails**<span offset-key="894b71832fd540699a5f0694b8b3524c:2"> and </span>**Django**<span offset-key="894b71832fd540699a5f0694b8b3524c:4">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="2f910e27f92f4f74a0f842943a7f468a"><span offset-key="2f910e27f92f4f74a0f842943a7f468a:0">We are forced to make more decisions due to the flexibility and control it provides.</span></span>

# 

<span key="bc2590c2ee304c09bbf861689c9a5e70"><span offset-key="bc2590c2ee304c09bbf861689c9a5e70:0">Main Features of Express</span></span>

<span key="ef4dcf9dcacc49079ef104e77a73dabf"><span offset-key="ef4dcf9dcacc49079ef104e77a73dabf:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://expressjs.com/en/guide/writing-middleware.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f61fc8734d044f2080854f9bec63d0fa" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="752c43c01dde44a4a75ef1bfc9d3d4b6"><span data-offset-key="752c43c01dde44a4a75ef1bfc9d3d4b6:0">Writing middleware for use in Express appsMiddleware functions are functions that have access to the request object ( req), the response object ( res), and the…expressjs.com</span></span></span></a><span key="87b21b3f99274173937b6beb4c9414fa"><span offset-key="87b21b3f99274173937b6beb4c9414fa:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="69262040046d4d7c9407c5b4902a14af"></span>

<span key="b0811d3ad74747e0aa2a7c3e09f8bfef"><span offset-key="b0811d3ad74747e0aa2a7c3e09f8bfef:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="d2ce55c0bce14ca6a19efa2df9533a6d"><span offset-key="d2ce55c0bce14ca6a19efa2df9533a6d:0">Middleware</span></span>

<span key="30b61c7386a242e5818e44f2aa0c783f"><span offset-key="30b61c7386a242e5818e44f2aa0c783f:0">Middleware functions can get the request and response objects, operate on them, and (when specified) trigger some action. Examples are logging or security.</span></span>

<span key="37f5a51140ec43eea3881e80b717690c"><span offset-key="37f5a51140ec43eea3881e80b717690c:0">Express’s middleware stack is an array of functions.</span></span>

<span key="649c11a4eb8c4d3cb8e2d18bd4714d9d"><span offset-key="649c11a4eb8c4d3cb8e2d18bd4714d9d:0">Middleware </span>*can*<span offset-key="649c11a4eb8c4d3cb8e2d18bd4714d9d:2"> change the request or response, but it doesn’t have to.</span></span>

# 

<span key="9701878b8e35443ebcb8e358f78dc949"><span offset-key="9701878b8e35443ebcb8e358f78dc949:0">Routing</span></span>

<span key="861a2791a97843a59812c38bcf45375b"><span offset-key="861a2791a97843a59812c38bcf45375b:0">Routing is a way to select which request handler function is executed. It does so based on the URL visited and the HTTP method used. Routing provides a way to break an application into smaller parts.</span></span>

# 

<span key="addfd347993e4de4bd4c08d786b2b432"><span offset-key="addfd347993e4de4bd4c08d786b2b432:0">Routers for Application Modularity</span></span>

<span key="5232832b5bc545a4b312bf5a07a1fb6a"><span offset-key="5232832b5bc545a4b312bf5a07a1fb6a:0">We can break up applications into </span>**routers**<span offset-key="5232832b5bc545a4b312bf5a07a1fb6a:2">. We could have a router to serve our SPA and another router for our API. Each router can have its own middleware and routing. This combination provides improved functionality.</span></span>

# 

<span key="e521bea7386841b08d7db9142699bc6a"><span offset-key="e521bea7386841b08d7db9142699bc6a:0">Convenience Helpers</span></span>

<span key="ce023393bd6a4008b22344246aebe142"><span offset-key="ce023393bd6a4008b22344246aebe142:0">Express has many helpers that provide out of the box functionality to make writing web applications and API servers easier.</span></span>

<span key="3da2ad9f595b40e2b260adb097d954ce"><span offset-key="3da2ad9f595b40e2b260adb097d954ce:0">A lot of those helpers are extension methods added to the request and response objects.</span></span>

<span key="285eaf4135a144b4b82478e4009f70f8"><span offset-key="285eaf4135a144b4b82478e4009f70f8:0">Examples </span></span><a href="https://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="57a526b989bf43089f51f4da553d41ba" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="627391996ead4bdebe8771bec01a9222"><span data-offset-key="627391996ead4bdebe8771bec01a9222:0">from the Api Reference (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619"><span offset-key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619:0"> include: </span>`response.redirect()`<span offset-key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619:2">, </span>`response.status()`<span offset-key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619:4">, </span>`response.send()`<span offset-key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619:6">, and </span>`request.ip`<span offset-key="c34f89559a7a4274ba6806f07b7b7619:8">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6daec18be0d64ee5a28e47fee89e926b"><span offset-key="6daec18be0d64ee5a28e47fee89e926b:0">Views</span></span>

<span key="c71fee16b4dc45c1826e0e56634a1d18"><span offset-key="c71fee16b4dc45c1826e0e56634a1d18:0">Views provide a way to dynamically render HTML on the server and even generate it using other languages.</span></span>

# 

<span key="304504e4a6734ea29498ba023b22b9ca"><span offset-key="304504e4a6734ea29498ba023b22b9ca:0">Try It:</span></span>

<span key="0e3199931c6f4e6499617bf2c12d36aa"><span offset-key="0e3199931c6f4e6499617bf2c12d36aa:0">Let’s write our first server using Express:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="15f8d8d745534fbf89be7bffca31df7d"><span offset-key="15f8d8d745534fbf89be7bffca31df7d:0">Create a new file called </span>`server.js`<span offset-key="15f8d8d745534fbf89be7bffca31df7d:2"> to host our server code.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0ac52e01444146f6b807070f8ee02579"><span offset-key="0ac52e01444146f6b807070f8ee02579:0">Type </span>`npm init -y`<span offset-key="0ac52e01444146f6b807070f8ee02579:2"> to generate a </span>`package.json`<span offset-key="0ac52e01444146f6b807070f8ee02579:4">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="93af2535f17b4ebb99dcf5413cbeca7e"><span offset-key="93af2535f17b4ebb99dcf5413cbeca7e:0">Install the </span>`express`<span offset-key="93af2535f17b4ebb99dcf5413cbeca7e:2"> npm module using: </span>`npm install express`<span offset-key="93af2535f17b4ebb99dcf5413cbeca7e:4">.</span></span>

<span key="ae10bf549af24b89b33d4a47a0a504a2"><span offset-key="ae10bf549af24b89b33d4a47a0a504a2:0">Inside </span>`server.js`<span offset-key="ae10bf549af24b89b33d4a47a0a504a2:2"> add the following code:</span></span>

1

<span key="5c94bbe9c3fe4d49b55a300674907ecf"><span offset-key="5c94bbe9c3fe4d49b55a300674907ecf:0">const express = require('express'); // import the express packageconst server = express(); // creates the server// handle requests to the root of the api, the / route</span></span>

2

<span key="a55705dc2b994a96b603e66df5daaa7b"><span offset-key="a55705dc2b994a96b603e66df5daaa7b:0">server.get('/', (req, res) => {</span></span>

3

<span key="9f940d09b0fd4060b2d509065451b70c"><span offset-key="9f940d09b0fd4060b2d509065451b70c:0"> res.send('Hello from Express');</span></span>

4

<span key="6c872135f1c94e38ba7e5e0dff407255"><span offset-key="6c872135f1c94e38ba7e5e0dff407255:0">});// watch for connections on port 5000</span></span>

5

<span key="ca93513f17a8449fadd10adcd8c0aac4"><span offset-key="ca93513f17a8449fadd10adcd8c0aac4:0">server.listen(5000, () =></span></span>

6

<span key="e6bb2cbc9aa74d5db38d22d10f053792"><span offset-key="e6bb2cbc9aa74d5db38d22d10f053792:0"> console.log('Server running on &lt;http://localhost:5000>')</span></span>

7

<span key="dafbae0a12ff4ee5b726957b45c009c7"><span offset-key="dafbae0a12ff4ee5b726957b45c009c7:0">);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="753ca4c41fe142559115b3b8873b8d35"><span offset-key="753ca4c41fe142559115b3b8873b8d35:0">Run the server by typing: </span>`node server.js`<span offset-key="753ca4c41fe142559115b3b8873b8d35:2"> and visit </span>`http://localhost:5000`<span offset-key="753ca4c41fe142559115b3b8873b8d35:4"> in the browser.</span></span>

<span key="b3e7514a8c044faea3a5b9dbcdd32005"><span offset-key="b3e7514a8c044faea3a5b9dbcdd32005:0">To stop the server, type </span>`Ctrl + c`<span offset-key="b3e7514a8c044faea3a5b9dbcdd32005:2"> at the terminal window.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6222a3570ae9431db1ee11989bcd1b76"><span offset-key="6222a3570ae9431db1ee11989bcd1b76:0">Create an API that can respond to GET requests</span></span>

<span key="e8402e22d8ac4e92b932a88b01061d2a"><span offset-key="e8402e22d8ac4e92b932a88b01061d2a:0">The steps necessary to build a simple Web API that returns the string “Hello World” on every incoming </span>`GET`<span offset-key="e8402e22d8ac4e92b932a88b01061d2a:2"> request. The program should return the string every time a request comes into the root route ("/"). For now, you don't need to code along, just read through the steps.</span></span>

<span key="63ef3de57972442d888883253ba9438d"><span offset-key="63ef3de57972442d888883253ba9438d:0">To make things easier, we’ll use an existing repository as the base for our API. Later in the week, as we learn more about Node.js and Express, we’ll create an API from scratch.</span></span>

<span key="b96c2ceb33a246d2843d8f602b14f968"><span offset-key="b96c2ceb33a246d2843d8f602b14f968:0">To build our first API, we will:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="4c81d8ebf5ab4669bde20930f8d4a15d"><span offset-key="4c81d8ebf5ab4669bde20930f8d4a15d:0">clone the </span></span><a href="https://github.com/LambdaSchool/node-express-mini" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bc00f2a7e0db4e83844194e4bd1c36f7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="785b43403be044adb8b80c9f57e46f96"><span data-offset-key="785b43403be044adb8b80c9f57e46f96:0">node-express-mini repository (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="d974410e970a4e3d9c809458c80067c1"><span offset-key="d974410e970a4e3d9c809458c80067c1:0"> to a folder on our computer.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="eb0bffc6a64b4e33b859a5305cc4ecc3"><span offset-key="eb0bffc6a64b4e33b859a5305cc4ecc3:0">Navigate into the folder using </span>`cd`<span offset-key="eb0bffc6a64b4e33b859a5305cc4ecc3:2">.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">3.</span>
    <span key="803064cecfda4795b3e275b8f638cd1b"><span offset-key="803064cecfda4795b3e275b8f638cd1b:0">Use </span>`npm install`<span offset-key="803064cecfda4795b3e275b8f638cd1b:2"> to download all dependencies.</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">4.</span>
    <span key="2d42ef3a258b47dcb447d1fe434fcb4a"><span offset-key="2d42ef3a258b47dcb447d1fe434fcb4a:0">Add a file called </span>`index.js`<span offset-key="2d42ef3a258b47dcb447d1fe434fcb4a:2"> at the folder's root, next to the </span>`package.json`<span offset-key="2d42ef3a258b47dcb447d1fe434fcb4a:4"> file.</span></span>

5.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">5.</span>
    <span key="bd0e3b8d56bf4b9b8becc09f5ec4b84b"><span offset-key="bd0e3b8d56bf4b9b8becc09f5ec4b84b:0">Open the </span>`index.js`<span offset-key="bd0e3b8d56bf4b9b8becc09f5ec4b84b:2"> file using our favorite code editor.</span></span>

6.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">6.</span>
    <span key="74071ff268764674af0f9772c4447e10"><span offset-key="74071ff268764674af0f9772c4447e10:0">Add the following code:</span></span>

1

<span key="e3f759a0ff644ca298b56a8f63f2ed77"><span offset-key="e3f759a0ff644ca298b56a8f63f2ed77:0">// require the express npm module, needs to be added to the project using "npm install express"</span></span>

2

<span key="b4d738c685ca42858e20c6aca02b52d3"><span offset-key="b4d738c685ca42858e20c6aca02b52d3:0">const express = require('express');// creates an express application using the express module</span></span>

3

<span key="54c9a57c0c914810bc966d064af5cf49"><span offset-key="54c9a57c0c914810bc966d064af5cf49:0">const server = express();// configures our server to execute a function for every GET request to "/"</span></span>

4

<span key="8105d725bbac466d968f46829650733b"><span offset-key="8105d725bbac466d968f46829650733b:0">// the second argument passed to the .get() method is the "Route Handler Function"</span></span>

5

<span key="83512c6225a84d71aca221fb5ec20ab4"><span offset-key="83512c6225a84d71aca221fb5ec20ab4:0">// the route handler function will run on every GET request to "/"</span></span>

6

<span key="1ecc72a5c8194777a09be01b90a43003"><span offset-key="1ecc72a5c8194777a09be01b90a43003:0">server.get('/', (req, res) => {</span></span>

7

<span key="278d6dd43c744c129113eda92c0e78a6"><span offset-key="278d6dd43c744c129113eda92c0e78a6:0"> // express will pass the request and response objects to this function</span></span>

8

<span key="fd9345eb0b5f47659759836f00d3d9d4"><span offset-key="fd9345eb0b5f47659759836f00d3d9d4:0"> // the .send() on the response object can be used to send a response to the client</span></span>

9

<span key="a52a34e95fe14f3d8d1ebfa04c2aed8f"><span offset-key="a52a34e95fe14f3d8d1ebfa04c2aed8f:0"> res.send('Hello World');</span></span>

10

<span key="84fe6f7909e845a998bf011046615845"><span offset-key="84fe6f7909e845a998bf011046615845:0">});// once the server is fully configured we can have it "listen" for connections on a particular "port"</span></span>

11

<span key="c8784363723344ebbf2c0b3c85078d13"><span offset-key="c8784363723344ebbf2c0b3c85078d13:0">// the callback function passed as the second argument will run once when the server starts</span></span>

12

<span key="271a533e7adf411a911ced64f572e3e0"><span offset-key="271a533e7adf411a911ced64f572e3e0:0">server.listen(8000, () => console.log('API running on port 8000'));</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9fad076c52534986bd65f8be04bfb37e">**make sure to save your changes to** **`index.js`.**</span>

<span key="fb6380867c4449cdba520dff9000a64b"><span offset-key="fb6380867c4449cdba520dff9000a64b:0">We are using the </span>`express`<span offset-key="fb6380867c4449cdba520dff9000a64b:2"> npm module in our code, so we need to add it as a dependency to our project. To do this:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="ae8e877d42b64518b457b48c95d39037"><span offset-key="ae8e877d42b64518b457b48c95d39037:0">Open a terminal/console/command prompt window and navigate to the root of our project.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="fd0535f125f2487cbd4042889c9aaf77"><span offset-key="fd0535f125f2487cbd4042889c9aaf77:0">Add express to our </span>`package.json`<span offset-key="fd0535f125f2487cbd4042889c9aaf77:2"> file by typing </span>`npm install express`<span offset-key="fd0535f125f2487cbd4042889c9aaf77:4">.</span></span>

<span key="f93162feff8f4527aea5a0737eaffacc"><span offset-key="f93162feff8f4527aea5a0737eaffacc:0">Now we’re ready to test our API!</span></span>

<span key="ea708808ef194967927eaaa70930d168"><span offset-key="ea708808ef194967927eaaa70930d168:0">In the terminal, still at the root of our project:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="3606b73b398a4b40928ee6dc58c70797"><span offset-key="3606b73b398a4b40928ee6dc58c70797:0">Type: </span>`npm run server`<span offset-key="3606b73b398a4b40928ee6dc58c70797:2"> to run our API. The message </span>*"Api running on port 8000"*<span offset-key="3606b73b398a4b40928ee6dc58c70797:4"> should appear on the terminal.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="7518a6f9b96344aa8cf88f5fa66f62e4"><span offset-key="7518a6f9b96344aa8cf88f5fa66f62e4:0">Open a web browser and navigate to “</span></span><a href="http://localhost:8000" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="82ae1d845236414dbf4861c6a22bdddc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="abdc8bd9f73a4c6bb6cf20a336caaf64"><span data-offset-key="abdc8bd9f73a4c6bb6cf20a336caaf64:0">http://localhost:8000</span></span></span></a><span key="13c67e3b413441c6a4d53421260ec9d5"><span offset-key="13c67e3b413441c6a4d53421260ec9d5:0">".</span></span>

<span key="c5fe40bf574d41a5b7dea00e6fc07ab8"><span offset-key="c5fe40bf574d41a5b7dea00e6fc07ab8:0">There we have it, our first API!</span></span>

<span key="2c4011e88df34c5485f70f5d847df96c"><span offset-key="2c4011e88df34c5485f70f5d847df96c:0">A lot is going on in those few lines of code (only six lines if we remove the comments and white space). We will cover every piece of it in detail over the following modules, but here is a quick rundown of the most important concepts.</span></span>

<span key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe"><span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:0">First, we used </span>`require()`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:2"> to </span>**import**<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:4"> the </span>`express module`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:6"> and make it available to our application. </span>`require()`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:8"> is similar to the </span>`import`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:10"> keyword we have used before. The line </span>`const express =                                         require('express');`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:12"> is equivalent to </span>`import express from                                         'express';`<span offset-key="782a6687a4f9423abf244b549d62e2fe:14"> if we were using ES2015 syntax.</span></span>

<span key="993df4088e6a49228a036a7a1c25c17c"><span offset-key="993df4088e6a49228a036a7a1c25c17c:0">The following line creates our Express application. The return of calling </span>`express()`<span offset-key="993df4088e6a49228a036a7a1c25c17c:2"> is an instance of an Express application that we can use to configure our </span>**server**<span offset-key="993df4088e6a49228a036a7a1c25c17c:4"> and, eventually, start listening for and responding to requests. Notice we use the word server, not API. An Express application is generic, which means we can use it to serve static content (HTML, CSS, audio, video, PDFs, and more). We can also use an Express application to serve dynamically generated web pages, build real-time communications servers, and more. We will use it statically to accept requests from clients and respond with data in JSON format.</span></span>

<span key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1"><span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:0">An Express application publishes a set of methods we can use to configure functions. We are using the </span>`.get()`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:2"> method to set up a </span>**route handler**<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:4"> function that will run on every </span>`GET`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:6"> request. As a part of this handler function, we specify the URL which will trigger the request. In this case, the URL is the site's root (represented by a </span>`/`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:8">). There are also methods to handle the </span>`POST`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:10">, </span>`PUT`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:12">, and </span>`DELETE`<span offset-key="64d542ab9a5941ecb2cb7ebe081c48e1:14"> HTTP verbs.</span></span>

<span key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267"><span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:0">The first two arguments passed by </span>`express`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:2"> to a route handler function are 1) an object representing the </span>`request`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:4"> and 2) an object representing the </span>`response`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:6">. Express expands those objects with a set of useful properties and methods. Our example uses the </span>`.send()`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:8"> method of the response object to specify the data we will send to the client as the response body. You can call the first two arguments anything you want, but it is prevalent to see them dubbed </span>`req`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:10"> and </span>`res`<span offset-key="4c08809ca735417a93c4415ef9ea1267:12">.</span></span>

<span key="c6645dadda8249aab63e8163714cf578"><span offset-key="c6645dadda8249aab63e8163714cf578:0">That’s all the configuring we need to do for this first example We’ll see other ways of configuring our server as we go forward.</span></span>

<span key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6"><span offset-key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6:0">After configuring the server, it’s time to turn it on. We use the </span>`.listen()`<span offset-key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6:2"> method to monitor a port on the computer for any incoming connections and respond to those we have configured. Our server will only respond to </span>`GET`<span offset-key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6:4"> requests made to the </span>`/`<span offset-key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6:6"> route on port </span>`8000`<span offset-key="ac963c5c6e7148a2bc9108256ffbeff6:8">.</span></span>

<span key="57b2f42fdd39469b8c42d68058f9609b"><span offset-key="57b2f42fdd39469b8c42d68058f9609b:0">That’s it for our first Web API, and now it’s time for you to follow along as we add a new </span>**endpoint**<span offset-key="57b2f42fdd39469b8c42d68058f9609b:2"> to our server that returns JSON data!</span></span>

<span key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876"><span offset-key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876:0">We should provide as much useful information as possible to the clients using our API. One such piece of data is the </span>`HTTP status code`<span offset-key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876:2"> that reflects the client's operation outcome. In this case, the client is trying to get a list of a particular </span>`resource`<span offset-key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876:4">, a </span>`hobbits`<span offset-key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876:6"> list. Sending back a </span>`200 OK`<span offset-key="8d032ad9eb45495b99c18de54e33e876:8"> status code communicates to the client that the operation was successful.</span></span>

<span key="f26db6562d884f6b8b28abd9367ac531"><span offset-key="f26db6562d884f6b8b28abd9367ac531:0">We will see other status codes as we continue to build new endpoints during this week. You can see a list by following </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="71ac50862fd240b4be89610ea8f2665e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-62800_259-62801-237__"><span data-key="2fc0ef65971e403196ef6bde0d87f1cc"><span data-offset-key="2fc0ef65971e403196ef6bde0d87f1cc:0">this link to the documentation about HTTP Response Codes on the Mozilla Developer Network site (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="c29313cc895b45f49a3af82967a7a7ec"><span offset-key="c29313cc895b45f49a3af82967a7a7ec:0">.</span></span>

<span key="d2cb80837b544231a04d0064d0b998cc"><span offset-key="d2cb80837b544231a04d0064d0b998cc:0">We can use the </span>`.status()`<span offset-key="d2cb80837b544231a04d0064d0b998cc:2"> method of the response object to send any valid </span>`HTTP status code`<span offset-key="d2cb80837b544231a04d0064d0b998cc:4">.</span></span>

<span key="233fde1dc06e452db68e868cc77e2553"><span offset-key="233fde1dc06e452db68e868cc77e2553:0">We are also chaining the </span>`.json()`<span offset-key="233fde1dc06e452db68e868cc77e2553:2"> method of the response object. We do this to communicate to both the client making the request and the next developer working with this code that we intend to send the data in </span>`JSON format`<span offset-key="233fde1dc06e452db68e868cc77e2553:4">.</span></span>

<span key="2972661fd11345ec86e40618716fb963"><span offset-key="2972661fd11345ec86e40618716fb963:0">Two things to note:</span></span>

<span key="5771f0e986614a749836cda4c51d0c44"><span offset-key="5771f0e986614a749836cda4c51d0c44:0">How does the client let the API know which hobbit should be deleted or updated? One way, the one we’ll use, is through </span>`route parameters`<span offset-key="5771f0e986614a749836cda4c51d0c44:2">. Let's add support for route parameters to our </span>`DELETE`<span offset-key="5771f0e986614a749836cda4c51d0c44:4"> endpoint.</span></span>

<span key="384b3e1877f8498e80e83df978354813"><span offset-key="384b3e1877f8498e80e83df978354813:0">We define route parameters by adding it to the URL with a colon (</span>`:`<span offset-key="384b3e1877f8498e80e83df978354813:2">) in front of it. Express adds it to the </span>`.params`<span offset-key="384b3e1877f8498e80e83df978354813:4"> property part of the request object. Let's see it in action:</span></span>

1

<span key="792cc0ff9d184cbdb8dda03cbde75418"><span offset-key="792cc0ff9d184cbdb8dda03cbde75418:0">server.delete('/hobbits/:id', (req, res) => {</span></span>

<span key="a697e37a1bbc4a37a43755f969d3ca46"><span offset-key="a697e37a1bbc4a37a43755f969d3ca46:0"> // or we could destructure it like so: const { id } = req.params;</span></span>

<span key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14"><span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:0">This route handler will execute every </span>`DELETE`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:2"> for a URL that begins with </span>`/hobbits/`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:4"> followed by any value. So, </span>`DELETE`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:6"> requests to </span>`/hobbits/123`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:8"> and </span>`/hobbits/frodo`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:10"> will both trigger this request handler. The value passed after </span>`/hobbits/`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:12"> will end up as the </span>`id`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:14"> property on </span>`req.params`<span offset-key="8564bba6853248579ca77113739a7c14:16">.</span></span>

<span key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43"><span offset-key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43:0">The value for a route parameter will always be </span>`string`<span offset-key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43:2">, even if the value passed is numeric. When hitting </span>`/hobbits/123`<span offset-key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43:4"> in our example, the type of </span>`req.params.id`<span offset-key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43:6"> will be </span>`string`<span offset-key="e83a6f461df44cb5a9e344058a282e43:8">.</span></span>

<span key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147"><span offset-key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147:0">Express routing has support for multiple route parameters. For example, defining a route URL that reads </span>`/hobbits/:id/friends/:friendId`<span offset-key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147:2">, will add properties for </span>`id`<span offset-key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147:4"> and </span>`friendId`<span offset-key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147:6"> to </span>`req.params`<span offset-key="d18d43e4454c49e2ab599d06766d5147:8">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="a68c6a40a2cf4ecabca7bbf0b13d2825"><span offset-key="a68c6a40a2cf4ecabca7bbf0b13d2825:0">Using the Query String</span></span>

<span key="8dfe5fbf89e34891aa9d06a71e9cf2de"><span offset-key="8dfe5fbf89e34891aa9d06a71e9cf2de:0">The query string is another strategy using the URL to pass information from clients to the server. The query string is structured as a set of key/value pairs. Each pair takes the form of </span>`key=value`<span offset-key="8dfe5fbf89e34891aa9d06a71e9cf2de:2">, and pairs are separated by an </span>`&`<span offset-key="8dfe5fbf89e34891aa9d06a71e9cf2de:4">. To mark the beginning of the query string, we add </span>`?`<span offset-key="8dfe5fbf89e34891aa9d06a71e9cf2de:6"> and the end of the URL, followed by the set of key/value pairs.</span></span>

<span key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8"><span offset-key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8:0">An example of a query string would be: </span>`https://www.google.com/search?q=lambda&tbo=1`<span offset-key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8:2">. The query string portion is </span>`?q=lambda&tbo=1`<span offset-key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8:4"> and the key/value pairs are </span>`q=lambda`<span offset-key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8:6"> and </span>`tbo=1`<span offset-key="413df94ade554f11983bbddcbc3489b8:8">.</span></span>

<span key="08775f6451624a87ae0e1eb085d7c190"><span offset-key="08775f6451624a87ae0e1eb085d7c190:0">Let’s add sorting capabilities to our API. We’ll provide a way for clients to hit our </span>`/hobbits`<span offset-key="08775f6451624a87ae0e1eb085d7c190:2"> and pass the field they want to use to sort the responses, and our API will sort the data by that field in ascending order.</span></span>

<span key="1c6ddf0521df49bd9b9fdbb21183f5c1"><span offset-key="1c6ddf0521df49bd9b9fdbb21183f5c1:0">Here’s the new code for the </span>`GET /hobbits`<span offset-key="1c6ddf0521df49bd9b9fdbb21183f5c1:2"> endpoint:</span></span>

1

<span key="80d56cfb792e4f45949f73bf59b62de3"><span offset-key="80d56cfb792e4f45949f73bf59b62de3:0">server.get('/hobbits', (req, res) => {</span></span>

10

<span key="fa47c16e2321412788c031af328e46d5"><span offset-key="fa47c16e2321412788c031af328e46d5:0"> id: 2,</span></span>

<span key="0c955e4e220d41aba5c0620e25829a16"><span offset-key="0c955e4e220d41aba5c0620e25829a16:0"> name: 'Frodo Baggins',</span></span>

<span key="ff60801ad1b0425482358f08310ebcac"><span offset-key="ff60801ad1b0425482358f08310ebcac:0"> (a, b) => (a\[sortField\] &lt; b\[sortField\] ? -1 : 1)</span></span>

<span key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77"><span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:0">Visit </span>`localhost:8000/hobbits?sortby=name`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:2">, and the list should be sorted by </span>`name`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:4">. Visit </span>`localhost:8000/hobbits?sortby=id`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:6">, and the list should now be sorted by </span>`id`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:8">. If no </span>`sortby`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:10"> parameter is provided, it should default to sorting by </span>`id`<span offset-key="74ddaa08bc564ff081ce61cf45169d77:12">.</span></span>

<span key="dd0408fc48654eecb0d8542d4bd228b0"><span offset-key="dd0408fc48654eecb0d8542d4bd228b0:0">To read values from the query string, we use the </span>`req.query`<span offset-key="dd0408fc48654eecb0d8542d4bd228b0:2"> object added by Express. There will be a key and a value in the </span>`req.query`<span offset-key="dd0408fc48654eecb0d8542d4bd228b0:4"> object for each key/value pair found in the query string.</span></span>

<span key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18"><span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:0">The parameter’s value will be of type </span>`array`<span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:2"> if more than one value is passed for the same key and </span>`string`<span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:4"> when only one value is passed. For example, in the query string </span>`?id=123`<span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:6">, </span>`req.query.id`<span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:8"> will be a string, but for </span>`?id=123&id=234`<span offset-key="dda960e2d7c24bb28c84084e00c5ce18:10">, it will be an array.</span></span>

<span key="293a532a46424572922716cfc014338a"><span offset-key="293a532a46424572922716cfc014338a:0">Another gotcha is that the names of query string parameters are case sensitive, </span>`sortby`<span offset-key="293a532a46424572922716cfc014338a:2"> and </span>`sortBy`<span offset-key="293a532a46424572922716cfc014338a:4"> are two different parameters.</span></span>

<span key="bf0b9985cc11436aa37ae071596f67d9"><span offset-key="bf0b9985cc11436aa37ae071596f67d9:0">The rest of the code sorts the array before sending it back to the client.</span></span>

# 

<span key="746f3f18c73f47328d8448d8f3dccc21"><span offset-key="746f3f18c73f47328d8448d8f3dccc21:0">Reading Data from the Request Body</span></span>

<span key="a08bf4d9e9f24b339b5063f0308ffcc1"><span offset-key="a08bf4d9e9f24b339b5063f0308ffcc1:0"> name: 'Bilbo Baggins',</span></span>

<span key="53664378328642de94c3a8bc16bf5292"><span offset-key="53664378328642de94c3a8bc16bf5292:0"> age: 111,</span></span>

7

<span key="35af56786b5b4f908d86896ada871861"><span offset-key="35af56786b5b4f908d86896ada871861:0"> },</span></span>

8

<span key="ba25236d326347e587f9fea82b59eaa4"><span offset-key="ba25236d326347e587f9fea82b59eaa4:0"> {</span></span>

9

<span key="abe549cc69464bf4ac6e385089affcf8"><span offset-key="abe549cc69464bf4ac6e385089affcf8:0"> id: 2,</span></span>

10

<span key="f0cd8ed38b6e47c485876bc0fd000840"><span offset-key="f0cd8ed38b6e47c485876bc0fd000840:0"> name: 'Frodo Baggins',</span></span>

11

<span key="e287c69318a34ffcb233060a1cb1ef6e"><span offset-key="e287c69318a34ffcb233060a1cb1ef6e:0"> age: 33,</span></span>

12

<span key="82184f8fe0114cc8a18a6ea405906baf"><span offset-key="82184f8fe0114cc8a18a6ea405906baf:0"> },</span></span>

13

<span key="73239f189e1449449ca358afb3beb8d4"><span offset-key="73239f189e1449449ca358afb3beb8d4:0">\];</span></span>

14

<span key="abb661a8cf9b44129da0caf0befc23a1"><span offset-key="abb661a8cf9b44129da0caf0befc23a1:0">let nextId = 3;// and modify the post endpoint like so:</span></span>

15

<span key="b1df5f80b4b448c181716a80a7147f71"><span offset-key="b1df5f80b4b448c181716a80a7147f71:0">server.post('/hobbits', (req, res) => {</span></span>

16

<span key="b3f4ea77b6a541d0aa170ba14b919630"><span offset-key="b3f4ea77b6a541d0aa170ba14b919630:0"> const hobbit = req.body;</span></span>

17

<span key="aea22f5f46954975884346e6bb6958e4"><span offset-key="aea22f5f46954975884346e6bb6958e4:0"> hobbit.id = nextId++; hobbits.push(hobbit); res.status(201).json(hobbits);</span></span>

18

<span key="127125642bef4c4dab1a854561db5861"><span offset-key="127125642bef4c4dab1a854561db5861:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="eeb86292b21e42548e78658ec7b09190"><span offset-key="eeb86292b21e42548e78658ec7b09190:0">To make this work with the hobbits array, we first move it out of the get endpoint into the outer scope. Now we have access to it from all route handlers.</span></span>

<span key="3d227b4c569c4416a05241c1431d3331"><span offset-key="3d227b4c569c4416a05241c1431d3331:0">Then we define a variable for manual id generation. When using a database, this is not necessary as the database management system generates ids automatically.</span></span>

<span key="1066a4d287654e72b437f5ca452c17f3"><span offset-key="1066a4d287654e72b437f5ca452c17f3:0">To read data from the request body, we need to do two things:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="b045c4ca022e4d759e38268c1f400dd7"><span offset-key="b045c4ca022e4d759e38268c1f400dd7:0">Add the line: </span>`server.use(express.json());`<span offset-key="b045c4ca022e4d759e38268c1f400dd7:2"> after the express application has been created.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="2af22940fa314903abe4480d9118f236"><span offset-key="2af22940fa314903abe4480d9118f236:0">Read the data from the body property that Express adds to the request object. Express takes all the client’s information from the body and makes it available as a nice JavaScript object.</span></span>

<span key="9ad2b18e9d854770b54ecc37b8437434">**Note that we are skipping data validation to keep this demo simple, but in a production application, you would validate before attempting to save to the database.**</span>

<span key="665fb5e0e3bd4a93ade9bd11a82322a1"><span offset-key="665fb5e0e3bd4a93ade9bd11a82322a1:0">Let’s test it using Postman:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a13b86873eb2491a95594ad1f912d3e5"><span offset-key="a13b86873eb2491a95594ad1f912d3e5:0">Change the method to POST.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4f4138c8a48b487b8056a0049ad9ee1d"><span offset-key="4f4138c8a48b487b8056a0049ad9ee1d:0">Select the </span>`Body`<span offset-key="4f4138c8a48b487b8056a0049ad9ee1d:2"> tab underneath the address bar.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="40f90b4d2b814bd4bdff5e7144ceeefb"><span offset-key="40f90b4d2b814bd4bdff5e7144ceeefb:0">Click on the </span>`raw`<span offset-key="40f90b4d2b814bd4bdff5e7144ceeefb:2"> radio button.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="fbbe150af2334811be0e3b3a6c334dfe"><span offset-key="fbbe150af2334811be0e3b3a6c334dfe:0">From the dropdown menu to the right of the </span>`binary`<span offset-key="fbbe150af2334811be0e3b3a6c334dfe:2"> radio button, select \`JSON (application/json).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="77d6613a0cd3484595dd82311fd07049"><span offset-key="77d6613a0cd3484595dd82311fd07049:0">Add the following JSON object as the body:</span></span>

1

<span key="67f97ad4bff84bbeaadfd420ff1a4624"><span offset-key="67f97ad4bff84bbeaadfd420ff1a4624:0">{</span></span>

2

<span key="b7eea6b3c54942f8a88346ce3c1b9194"><span offset-key="b7eea6b3c54942f8a88346ce3c1b9194:0"> "name": "Samwise Gamgee",</span></span>

3

<span key="4836abc23c934180982641a4a2ca073d"><span offset-key="4836abc23c934180982641a4a2ca073d:0"> "age": 30</span></span>

4

<span key="4d4c1db53bd14b46b7ebfb8c375e708d"><span offset-key="4d4c1db53bd14b46b7ebfb8c375e708d:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="dbd450eeda2e4982a9b3f0b0ea173e3a"><span offset-key="dbd450eeda2e4982a9b3f0b0ea173e3a:0">Click on </span>`Send`<span offset-key="dbd450eeda2e4982a9b3f0b0ea173e3a:2">, and the API should return the list of hobbits, including Sam!</span></span>

# 

<span key="0727198d8ae4488e98fbf58c4d5b9a1d"><span offset-key="0727198d8ae4488e98fbf58c4d5b9a1d:0">Try It:</span></span>

<span key="3ea90adee3d64a73b01e2327b85194b3"><span offset-key="3ea90adee3d64a73b01e2327b85194b3:0">Please code along as we implement the </span>`PUT`<span offset-key="3ea90adee3d64a73b01e2327b85194b3:2"> endpoint and a way for the client to specify the sort direction.</span></span>

# 

<span key="d062144f65764955872dee11f1d66307"><span offset-key="d062144f65764955872dee11f1d66307:0">Implement Update Functionality</span></span>

<span key="73d88345d7134d3cae8cba3d1bb43ef8"><span offset-key="73d88345d7134d3cae8cba3d1bb43ef8:0">Let’s continue practicing reading route parameters and information from the request body. Let’s take a look at our existing PUT endpoint:</span></span>

1

<span key="8b953d76f6f14bc699aa85e5d9f483e8"><span offset-key="8b953d76f6f14bc699aa85e5d9f483e8:0">server.put('/hobbits', (req, res) => {</span></span>

2

<span key="e281c0421c91426a923a3327e7b42f5b"><span offset-key="e281c0421c91426a923a3327e7b42f5b:0"> res.status(200).json({ url: '/hobbits', operation: 'PUT' });</span></span>

3

<span key="509cbcebc6ae45fd81a707d38b8781c4"><span offset-key="509cbcebc6ae45fd81a707d38b8781c4:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4adcd45d29754a2d9aa5bf0ac78335ca"><span offset-key="4adcd45d29754a2d9aa5bf0ac78335ca:0">We start by adding support for a route parameter the clients can use to specify the id of the hobbit they intend to update:</span></span>

1

<span key="ab9b7ede918545459730a361e6b6d339"><span offset-key="ab9b7ede918545459730a361e6b6d339:0">server.put('/hobbits/:id', (req, res) => {</span></span>

2

<span key="b7eca2c8dbbe43b8b6c44aab7f394607"><span offset-key="b7eca2c8dbbe43b8b6c44aab7f394607:0"> res.status(200).json({ url: '/hobbits', operation: 'PUT' });</span></span>

3

<span key="b4ad95f898b84bc199a8578676d65393"><span offset-key="b4ad95f898b84bc199a8578676d65393:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7f22898fab5a46e09ee7301a8a016987"><span offset-key="7f22898fab5a46e09ee7301a8a016987:0">Next, we read the hobbit information from the request body using </span>`req.body`<span offset-key="7f22898fab5a46e09ee7301a8a016987:2"> and use it to update the existing hobbit.</span></span>

1

<span key="c561e12e905644cab3a43df7a0b2788b"><span offset-key="c561e12e905644cab3a43df7a0b2788b:0">server.put('/hobbits/:id', (req, res) => {</span></span>

2

<span key="2a1830d707504542badd564f04d229c0"><span offset-key="2a1830d707504542badd564f04d229c0:0"> const hobbit = hobbits.find(h => h.id == req.params.id); if (!hobbit) {</span></span>

3

<span key="70849adf72fc4ffba7b94a3f9467efd4"><span offset-key="70849adf72fc4ffba7b94a3f9467efd4:0"> res.status(404).json({ message: 'Hobbit does not exist' });</span></span>

4

<span key="aa8e9109f69845aba4d2276b0036feb4"><span offset-key="aa8e9109f69845aba4d2276b0036feb4:0"> } else {</span></span>

5

<span key="bc1da6914119464dbbfed9d4337b2f33"><span offset-key="bc1da6914119464dbbfed9d4337b2f33:0"> // modify the existing hobbit</span></span>

6

<span key="5e13564b73b542729f2b5210980e2d86"><span offset-key="5e13564b73b542729f2b5210980e2d86:0"> Object.assign(hobbit, req.body); res.status(200).json(hobbit);</span></span>

7

<span key="a4409029a63b465ab0ef0abeeeb673fb"><span offset-key="a4409029a63b465ab0ef0abeeeb673fb:0"> }</span></span>

8

<span key="b4c424accba4494d81bab334a2acc2ea"><span offset-key="b4c424accba4494d81bab334a2acc2ea:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7024a1d9b3464d4688f3977ec45b2579"><span offset-key="7024a1d9b3464d4688f3977ec45b2579:0">Concentrate on the code related to reading the </span>`id`<span offset-key="7024a1d9b3464d4688f3977ec45b2579:2"> from the </span>`req.params`<span offset-key="7024a1d9b3464d4688f3977ec45b2579:4"> object and reading the hobbit information from </span>`req.body`<span offset-key="7024a1d9b3464d4688f3977ec45b2579:6">. The rest of the code will change as this is a simple example using an in-memory array. Most production APIs will use a database.</span></span>
